ENMA, es una señorita muy alegre y trabajadora quien desde niña aprendió a vender en los mercados junto a sus padres, ahora tiene su propio negocio de venta de productos agrícolas y le va muy bien.Uno de los deseos de esta señorita es poder ser la mejor vendedora del lugar y hasta ahora lo está realizando de la mejor manera y sus vecinos así lo corroboran al ver su esfuerzo en su puesto de trabajo.Sin embargo Enma nos confiesa sus debilidades y limitaciones que tiene en cuanto a su negocio y está sumamente relacionado con el factor económico y a través de este medio busca que personas como ustedes puedan ayudarla en su negocio atendiendo su petición para la compra de mayor cantidad de productos y revenderlos a los más grandes comerciantes. Así también invertirlo sobre todo en el cultivo de papa en los terrenos de su padre.

loans.use: To increase her product range and optimize the sowing of potatoes.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Bertha

texts.es:
Bertha is a businesswoman and she works at the city market, selling potatoes. She has been doing this for more than four years and thanks to her land, she is able to meet the demand from the market. We came across her working at the market very cheerfully and in the company of her friends she is able to enjoy herself and combat the stress which other people give her. Due to her ability to sell, she can cope very well, and is an example to everyone. So she can continue working at this same pace, she needs financial capital so that she can expand her product range and she is applying for a loan so that she can transport her products.

Translated from [Spanish] by [Lisa Ritchie], Kiva Volunteer.

BERTHA, es comerciante y trabaja en el mercado de su ciudad, vende en el sector de papas y esta actividad la realiza hace más de 4 años y gracias a sus terrenos de cultivo puede abastecer la demanda del mercado.La encontramos en el mercado trabajando muy alegremente y en compañía de sus amigas puede hacer de su trabajo una diversión y combatir el estrés que a otras personas les produce el trabajo.Debido a su capacidad para las ventas, ella puede desenvolverse muy efectivamente siendo un ejemplo para todas las personas. Para que ella siga con el mismo ritmo de trabajo necesita de un capital de dinero para aumentar sus productos y solicita un préstamo para el transporte de sus productos.

loans.use: To rent a vehicle for transporting her goods.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Edith is a happy woman who every morning she goes out to sell products from the farm. She doesn't have a stand to make her sales so she set herself up in the entrance of the market of her city. She very gladly offers her products to the patrons. For Edith this work is beautiful because she always makes new friendships and she partakes of hours of company and this makes her work fun, leaving all the problems aside. She dedicates her time eagerly to her work, working to sell corn at the doors of the market. But now she's been thinking she'd like to purchase a stand where she can sell her products and she needs your support to do it. This stand will her her increase her family's income, and for this she is requesting a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

EDITH, es una alegre mujer que todas las mañanas sale a vender sus productos agrícolas y por la falta de un puesto para poder vender, se las ingenió para instalarse en la entrada del mercado de su ciudad donde muy alegremente ofrece sus productos a las personas.Para Edith este trabajo es muy hermoso porque siempre comparte con sus amistades horas de compañía y esto hace de su trabajo algo divertido dejando de lado los problemas, dedicándose íntegramente a su trabajo y así la vimos trabajando vendiendo su maíz en la puerta del mercado Pero ahora tiene pensado comprarse un puesto donde vender sus productos y requiere de su apoyo para adquirir este puesto que le ayudaría a aumentar sus ingresos familiares y solicita un préstamo.

loans.use: To acquire a stand within the safety and security of the market.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.es:
Taking care of her beloved children and to offer them an education is what drives the effort and daily work for Aurelia. She is humble but she is an examplary mother that keeps that same strength and integrity as when she gave the gift of life to her three beloved children. She left her husband for the constant physical abuse and she decided to go out on her own and provide her children a peaceful home. In complete harmony they started to rebuild their family and for this she had to endure countless hours of hard work, especially because when all this happened her three beloved children were just little ones. Today her children are of age and Aurelia dedicates her time to craftwork. She is a dilligent mother and she knights beautiful tights and socks and gloves that she sells in the community market in the city of Juliaca. Meanwhile her upstanding and loving children, in their spare time, they work hard providing transportation services with a tricycle and a motorcycle that they purchased as a combined effort. Aurelia requires a loan that will be invested in the purchase of a knitting machine, and indispensable took that will permit her work to run smoothly.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Salir adelante junto a sus queridos hijos y ofrecerles educación es lo que sostiene el esfuerzo y el trabajo diario de Doña Aurelia, humilde pero ejemplar madre que sigue manteniendo la misma entereza y fuerza que cuando les concedió el don de vida a sus 3 queridos hijos.Desde que se separó de su esposo por los constantes maltratos físicos que este le propiciaba decidió salir adelante sola y ofrecerles un hogar tranquilo y en completa armonía a sus retoños, para ello tuvo que pasar horas incansables de trabajo porque en ese entonces sus queridos hijos eran muy pequeños.Actualmente con sus hijos ya mayores Doña Aurelia viene dedicándose a la artesanía, esta diligente madre elabora hermosos calcetines y guantes que son comercializados en el mercado dominical de la ciudad de Juliaca, mientras que sus ejemplares y amorosos hijos en sus horas libres trabajan brindando servicios de movilidad en un triciclo y un mototaxi que adquirieron gracias al esfuerzo conjunto.Doña Aurelia requiere un préstamo para comprar una máquina de tejer, indispensable instrumento que le permitirá agilizar su trabajo.

loans.use: To purchase a knitting machine.

loans.name: Marta Isabel

texts.es:
My name is Marta Isabel G. Hernández, and I am a businesswoman. I started my business more than 10 years ago, selling children’s clothing in street markets in the towns around San Pedro Sacatepèquez where I live. My husband worked alongside me in the business, but as we have six children, we didn’t earn enough money just doing that. After a lot of effort, we managed to rent a stall in the market, and for the last year I have been selling frequently used products. I am asking for a loan so that I can invest in products that the customers demand and that I need to stock so as to increase my customer base. I am very happy as I have gradually seen my business grow. However, my dream is to finish paying for the market stall so that it is finally mine. Then I can enlarge it, and with the income from that, I can provide better education for my children--of the six, only 2 are in school--but I want all of them to go to school and do well.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer.

Soy Marta Isabel G. Hernández, soy comerciante. Inicie mi negocio vendiendo ropa para niños desde hace màs de 10 años, de forma ambulante en diferentes pueblos cercanos a San Pedro Sacatepèquez que es donde yo vivo, en el negocio nos ayudábamos con mi esposo, pero como ya tenemos 6 hijos y el dinero no es suficiente, con mucho esfuerzo empezamos a abonar un local en el mercado donde desde hace ya mas de un año vendo productos de consumo diario por lo que el crédito que solicito es para poder invertir en productos que los clientes piden y que necesito surtir para ganar más cliente, estoy muy contenta ya que poco a poco he visto crecer mi negocio. Pero mi sueño es terminar de pagar el local y que sea definitivamente mìo, y poder engrandecerlo y que pueda con ello ayudar a mejorar la educación de mis hijos ya que de los 6, solo 2 están estudiando pero quiero que todos vayan a la escuela y que se superen.

loans.use: To purchase frequently used products to sell in my store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Soeu

texts.en:
Soeu M., 29 years old, is a widow and has one child and a younger sister. Her child is a student and her younger sister stays at home and helps her. They all reside in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She works as a tailor to support her family, making an average of $8 per day.

Soeu is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase another sewing machine. She will use the rest of the loan, and some of her savings, to buy a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To purchase another sewing machine.

loans.name: Narin

texts.en:
Mrs. Narin H. lives in Trapaing Bey Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She sells Chinese noodles in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Piseth Chhem, is a policeman in the province. They have four children, one of whom works as a security guard while another one is employed in a garment factory. The remaining two study in the state school.

Although the family members have different business activities and jobs, their living conditions have not improved. To help improve their standard of living, Mrs. Narin H. is requesting a loan to buy more fish to sell in the market as a new business. Mrs. Narin H. previously obtained a loan from AMK to buy pigs for breeding.

(Mrs Narin H.'s husband is pictured on the right in the photo.)

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell in the market as a new business.

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van P., aged 31, is a mother of two and lives with her husband in the town of Siem Reap, Cambodia. She owns a small fast boat that ferries mostly tourists and some villagers to the island. On average, she earns $6 per day. Her husband is a curator and makes $8 per day. Most of the family live in the countryside and rear animals to earn additional income.

To earn additional income to support the family Van and her husband are requesting a Kiva loan them raise pigs for meat.

loans.use: To rear pigs

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny K. is a farmer in Kouk Pech Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Im Tep, is a subsistence farmer and is pictured on the left in the photo. Mrs. Ny K. has three children, all of whom attend state school.

Mrs. Ny K. faces a small problem in her plantation business because she has insufficient money to buy a cow cart to transport fertilizers to the rice field. Thus, Mrs. Ny K. is requesting a loan to buy a cow cart to solve this problem. Additionally, Mrs. Ny K. plans to use the rest of the loan to purchase more raw materials with which to make mats to sell for additional income.

loans.use: To buy a cow cart to transport fertilizers and purchase raw materials with which to make mats for sale

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong T. is 47 years old and has a small laundry business in a town in Siem Reap province, making about $3 a day. She is a widow and has four children, three who are employed and one who is a student.

Kong now is requesting a loan from Kiva to build a clean bathroom. This bathroom is not related to her business but it will give this family the dignity of a clean restroom. It will also benefit their health because hygiene and sanitation will not be a problem anymore

. (Mrs. T. was not available for a photo but her son is pictured above)

loans.use: To build a new bathroom

loans.name: Buy

texts.en:
Buy K., aged 46, is a mother of seven and works as a farmer in Siem Reap province. She plants both rice and vegetables and makes $2.50 per day. Her husband has been a truck conductor since 1999. He can earn about $5 of profit per day. Two of their children are married and live away from home, one daughter is a teacher, another child works selling groceries, and the others help their parents in the rice fields.

Growing rice and vegetable by depending on the weather alone is a shaky and unreliable farming method these days, and they do not have enough water for their crops. To make the rice crop grow faster Buy and her husband are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase fertilizer and a water pump, with the rest of the money being used to buy groceries for her child to increase sales.

(Mrs. Buy is pictured)

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, a water pump and grocery items.

loans.name: Ly Buth Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly B. is the leader of a group of six women in Krang Kontrorl Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a subsistence farmer and firewood seller. Mrs. Ly B. is 38 and the mother of four children, two of whom are enrolled in school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Yeon Arn, is a subsistence farmer and woodman. Aside from these business activities, Mrs. Ly B. sews palm leaves together serve as roof coverings, which she sells.

In her plantation business, Mrs. Ly B. faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy cows to work in the rice field. Thus, Mrs. Ly B. now is requesting a Kiva loan to buy cows to use as draft animals.

loans.use: To buy cows to use as draft animals.

loans.name: Vadim

texts.en:
Vadim D. is 21 years old. He lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. He used to work on a collective farm, but now he is engaged in his own business raising and selling livestock. Mr. D. applied to MicroInvest in 2008 when he heard from his brother about its suitable and advantageous loan terms. Thanks to a previous loan he has already been able to significantly improve his existing business. The income stability it generated helped him to repay the previous loan and to qualify successfully for the next loan level.

Now Mr. D. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $775.00 US to purchase a pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To purchase a pedigreed bull

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina K. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan and like many who live there, she raises and sells livestock. She is 27 years old, but despite her youth, she is an experienced entrepreneur. She is not only in the livestock business ― she also has been selling shish kebab at the local bazaar for many years.

Miss K. came to MicroInvest to ask for financial support for her existing livestock business. She is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $825.00 US to purchase a pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To purchase a pedigreed bull

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.en:
Mamlakat A. is 37 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She works on a collective farm. Her husband is a stock keeper and she is engaged in the family business of raising and selling livestock, a popular trade in the Asht region. Mrs. A. has 20 years’ experience with livestock, as she helped her mother take care of the animals when she was a child.

Mrs. A. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $625.00 US to build a cowshed area.

loans.use: To build a cowshed area

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
Sri W. is in the food business since a year ago. She sells small meals such as lontong sayur (boiled banana leaf covered rice dipped in coconut milk with vegetable), and spicy fruit salad. She also sells vegetables, cooking oil, rice, and other household basic necessities. Every morning her husband, Asraf, takes her to Tabanan market with a scooter to buy supplies for the meals she sells. While in the afternoon she buys the household necessity supplies. The profit she makes is enough to finance her family needs and save some for her children education. Sri W. and her family live in Tabanan in their own house. The house and the environment are fairly healthy. Her husband works as a security guard in an office complex in Bali.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

Sri W. (36) memiliki usaha warung makanan sejak setahun yang lalu. Adapun jenis makanan yang dijualnya antara lain; lontong sayur, rujak buah, makanan ringan serta ada juga kebutuhan rumah tangga lainnya seperti sayur dan sembako (minyak goreng, beras, dll). Setiap pagi dia diantar oleh suaminya,Asraf, menggunakan sepeda motor ke pasar Tabanan untuk belanja bahan untuk usaha warung makanannya. Untuk kebutuhan sembako, biasanya dia belanja pada sore hari. Keuntungan yang didapat dari usaha warung makanan ini cukup untuk membiayai kebutuhan keluarganya dan juga menabung sedikit untuk kebutuhan sekolah kedua anaknya. Saat ini, Sri W. bersama keluarganya tinggal di Tabanan dengan menempati rumah sendiri. Keadaan rumah dan lingkungannya cukup sehat. Suaminya saat ini bekerja sebagai SATPAM disebuah perkantoran di Bali.

loans.use: To add business capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Zulfiniso

texts.en:
D. Zulfiniso is 43 years old. She is a widow and has two children.
About eight years ago, her family's financial situation forced Zulfiniso to start her own business. She decided to sell the fabrics used for making national dresses. Over time, her family's financial situation improved due to the profit generated by Zulfiniso’s business. Zulfiniso tries to diversify the range of goods she offers, so that she can meet the demand of the clients with various tastes and levels of income. Typically, she purchases the fabrics from wholesale markets in a neighboring city. Zulfiniso is doing her best in order to make her children well-educated and to provide them with other opportunities in the future.
Currently, Zulfiniso needs a loan of US$300 for a term of 3 months to be able to purchase more fabrics for sale. Having showed herself as a reliable client, Zulfiniso promises to repay also this loan on time and expresses her gratitude to everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: Purchase of a variety of new fabrics for sale

loans.name: Ravshanoi

texts.en:
Ravshanoi N. lives in the high mountain Asht region of Tajikistan where she raises and sells livestock, like many other local people. Mrs. N. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2008, and she has shown herself to be a serious entrepreneur. Mrs. N. works also on a collective farm. Her husband went to the Russian Federation for a well-paying job, so now Mrs. N. works to raise her child on her own.

Mrs. N. is asking KIVA for a business support loan of $625.00 US to build a cowshed.

loans.use: To build a cowshed

loans.name: Husen

texts.en:
S. Husen is 34 years old, married, and has three children of school age. 
Together with his wife, Husen earns income selling children's clothing and shoes in a store. The store is located in the central market of the town. Husen has been in this business already for 10 years. In order to be able to offer a wide range of goods for any taste and level of income, Husen almost every month travels to the neighboring town Istaravshan to purchase new goods. During his absence, Husen’s wife, pictured in the photo, helps him in the market. Husen has managed to increase his clientele, but he is still not able to fully meet the demand. Therefore, he needs a loan of US$300 for a term of 3 months. With the help of the loan, Husen plans to increase the stock of goods at the store, so that he can earn more income and provide his children with good education. This is Husen's first loan; however, he is sure that he will repay it on time. Husen is thankful to everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: Purchase of children's summer clothing for sale

loans.name: Robert

texts.id:
Robert’s (40) silversmith business has been going on for years. He employes three persons to help him doing the work and they are paid for more or less about USD 60, depending on the order they receive. This business is very promising, especially on holiday season when a lot of foreigner tourists are ordering silver craft from Robert. The income from the business is used for food and household necessity and some is saved for his children school needs. Robert needs the capital addition to be used to buy raw materials for his silversmith crafts.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha kerajinan perak yang dijalani oleh Robert (40) sudah berlangsung selama bertahun-tahun. Sampai saat ini dia sudah memiliki 3 orang pekerja yang membantunya membuat kerajinan perak. Setiap bulannya mereka dibayar rata-rata sekitar Rp.600,000. tapi juga bisa lebih atau kurang, tergantung banyaknya order yang diterima. Usaha kerajianan perak yang dimiliki oleh Robert sangat menjanjikan, apalagi dimusim kunjungan wisatawan asing, dimana banyak wisatawan yang memesan perak kepadanya. Penghasilan yang didapat dari usahanya, selain untuk makan dan kebutuhan keluarga, ada juga yang ditabung untuk kebutuhan sekolah anaknya. Saat ini Robert sangat membutuhkan modal untuk usahanya. Rencananya pinjaman kali ini akan digunakan untuk membeli bahan bahu untuk kerajinan peraknya.

loans.use: To ad business capital

loans.name: Zarrina

texts.en:
MicroInvest has been working with Mrs. Zarrina K. since 2008. She is a reliable entrepreneur who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. She lives in the Asht region and she is married, with 2 children. Her husband went to the Russian Federation to take a well-paying job. Mrs. K. works on a collective farm but her main business is raising livestock. She has 2 cows and 10 years’ experience in the livestock business. She has the appropriate skills and good knowledge of livestock care.

Mrs. K. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $625.00 US to purchase special milk handling equipment.

loans.use: To purchase special milk handling equipment

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat D. has been a client of MicroInvest since 2008. She lives in the Asht region and she is married, but her husband went to the Russian Federation to take a well-paying job. Mrs. D. works on a collective farm but the general business she is engaged in is raising livestock. She has 2 cows and some rams, and she has 30 years’ experience in the livestock business. She has the appropriate skills and good knowledge of livestock care.

Mrs. D. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $775.00 US to purchase a pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To purchase a pedigreed bull

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
S. Jamila is 39 years old, married, and has two children.
Jamila earns income selling such goods as batteries, blades, machine twist and treads, and pens. In addition, some days of the week, she sells blankets in a local market. Jamila has been in this business already for eight years. Her husband, pictured in the photograph, helps and supports her. Like all mothers, Jamila hopes that her children will be able to obtain higher education; threrefore, she and her husband are working very hard, and their business is successful in providing sufficient income for the family. Currently, Jamila needs a loan to be able to expand the business and to purchase new goods for sale. Therefore, she is asking for US$300 for a term of 3 months. Having borrowed from IMON already several times, and having demonstrated herself as a reliable client, Jamila promises to manage also this loan with accuracy.

loans.use: Expansion of a retail business and purchase of goods for sale

loans.name: Shahnozajon

texts.en: B. Shahnozajon is 23 years old. She is married and has two children of school age. Her husband is an entrepreneur. Shahnozajon and her husband are raising their children with love and try to provide them with everything that a teenager may need. In order to support her husband and increase their family budget, Shahnozajon has been running her own business for the past 4 years. She sells fabrics for the making of national Tajik dresses that are very popular and important for the dowry of any girl. All the fabrics are supplied from the neighboring wholesale market in Dushanbe. Shahnozajon has a rented trading place in a store. Being very polite and having a good taste, she has been able to attract many loyal customers. Shahnozajon tries to offer a wide range of goods to be able to meet the requirements of her customers and to satisfy the needs of the clients with different levels of income. She is therefore asking for a loan of US$1,000 that Shahnozajon will repay within 12 months and that will be spent for purchasing new, modern fabrics. She would like to thank everybody for supporting her.

loans.use: Purchase of new fabrics for sale

loans.name: Nyoman

texts.id:
Selling food is the daily business of Nyoman A. (39). By opening a small kiosk in front of her rent house, she opens the business from morning until night. Her morning day starts with walking to buy her kiosk supplies, regardless the far distance of the market from her home. Her husband income as a government staff can only meet their household necessity, leaving none to save. Therefore, she wants to help supporting her family economy which can help her children to go to school. She needs the loan to add more variety for her customer to choose from her kiosk and to attract more customers.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva Volunteer.

Usaha jualan makanan merupakan kegiatan sehari-hari yang dijalani oleh Nyoman A. (39). Dengan membuka warung kecil didepan rumah kontrakannya, dia biasanya berjualan dari pagi hingga malam hari. Dimulai dari pagi hari, dia berangkat untuk belanja bahan untuk kebutuhan warungnya dengan berjalan kaki, karena jarak dari rumahnya ke pasar tidak terlalu jauh. Penghasilan suaminya sebagai pegawai instansi pemerintah hanya cukup untuk membiayai rumah tangganya, tidak ada yang disisihkan utnk ditabung. Oleh karena itu dia juga ikut membantu meningkatkan ekonomi keluarga, sehingga nantinya bisa menabung untuk biaya sekolah anaknya. Sekarang ini, Nyoman A. membutuhkan modal untuk menambah jenis makanan diwarungnya, sehingga bisa lebih banyak pilihan, dan pembeli juga akan bertambah. Saat ini bersama keluarga, Nyoman A. tinggal disebuah rumah kontrakan di Perumahan Dalung Permai Denpasar.

loans.use: To add business capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Khanifa

texts.en: B. Khanifa is 57 years old. She is a widow and raised five children by herself. Thanks to Khanifa's effort, all of her children are married and have their own children now. Khanifa earns income selling make-up and cosmetics. She has been running her business already for ten years. Initially, Khanifa started it, because she did not have a job and needed to find a way to support her large family, being its only bread-winner. Khanifa is hoping to expand her business, to open her own store, and to establish constant supplies from well-known producers. Khanifa also dreams of having sufficient income to be able to provide her grand-children with good education, so that they one day become highly-demanded experts in their profession. Therefore, Khanifa is asking for a loan of US$600 in order to purchase a larger variety of make-up (lipsticks, mascaras, powder, skin cream, etc.) for sale. Khanifa would like to thank everybody for supporting her and promises to repay the loan within 12 months.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for sale

loans.name: Khaem

texts.en:
Khaem O. is 19 years old. Despite his young age, he already works and supports his parents. Khaem is an expert in computer services, for example, printing, scanning, lamination, and audio editing of video tapes and CDs with records of his clients' family events. Khaem has been in this business for already 2 years. He tries to use modern up-to-date technologies in his work to satisfy the demands and requirements of his customers. Currently, Khaem would like to purchase a new, modern computer in order to improve the quality of his work and to expand the business.
Therefore, he is requesting a loan of US$600 for a term of 12 months. This is his first loan, and Khaem is thankful to everyone for support. He promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of a new computer to improve the quality of his work

loans.name: Ansor

texts.en:
I. Ansor is 19 years old, single, and lives with his parents, financially supporting them.
Ansor has a minivan which he uses to provide transportation services for passengers in the city of Pendjikent. He has been in this business for the past 2 years. Initially, Ansor rented a car, but, with time, after saving some money, he bought his own minivan. The business is stable and generates the majority of income for Ansor’s family.
Currently, Ansor needs to purchase spare parts and to pay for the repair of the minivan, in order to be able to provide higher-quality transportation services. Therefore, he is asking for a loan of US$600 for a term of 12 months. This will be Ansor's first loan, and he promises everyone to do his best to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts in order to repair a minivan

loans.name: Khuraman

texts.en: Khuraman is a mother of 2 children. She was born in 1966.  This is a picture of Khuraman with her husband. They live in Khachmaz region. They started a cattle breeding business 8 years ago. Now this family requests a loan of $975 to buy 2 calves.  They promise to repay the loan in full on time.

loans.use: to buy 2 calves

loans.name: Shikhkarim

texts.en: Shikhkarim was born in 1953. He is married, has 3 children. S."s family lives in Khachmaz region. 10 years ago he started a farming business. Now he requests a loan of $975 to buy seedlings and fertilizer for his business.  He promises to repay the loan in full on time.

loans.use: to buy  seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Rem

texts.en:
Mrs. Rem K. is a subsistence farmer in Chhouk Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is 48 and a widow with six children, three of whom are employed in difference garment factories while the remaining three attend school.

In her plantation business, Mrs. Rem K. earns a small revenue because she owns just a small rice field. In order to expand her harvest, Mrs. Rem K. has decided to asked for a loan to buy a plot of land on which to grow rice. Mrs Rem K. obtained a loan from Amret Co.,Ltd in the past, and used the money to start a poultry business.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to grow rice.

loans.name: Abdul Saboor

texts.en:
Abdul Saboor, son of A. J., lives in the Sorkhrood district of the Ningarhar province. He is 41 years old, and he is the father of two children.

Abdul Saboor owns and operates a small retail shop in the Sorkhrood bazaar. He is an active man and wants to develop this small business to raise his income. For this purpose, he is seeking some money to buy many things for his shop. Specifically, he is hereby requesting a loan in the amount of $1,100 (50,000 Afghanis), which he promises to repay in 18 months.

loans.use: To further develop his growing business and to generate greater income by purchasing additional retail goods for his shop

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng M. sells a type of Khmer cake in Anlong Thnot Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Her husband, Mr. Yin Bich, is unemployed and assists his wife to make the Khmer cakes she sells. Mrs. Heng M. and her husband have six children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while four others attend school. The youngest is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Heng M. does her best to earn enough to support her family and give them better living conditions. However, she still does not have enough money to build a new house to replace their old one. Thus, Mrs. Heng M. has asked for a loan to help the family afford the cost of building a new house.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Lat

texts.en:
Mrs. Lat H. is 30 and lives in Anlong Tnot Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a Khmer cake seller and a farmer in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Ny In, is a subsistence farmer. Mrs. Lat H. and her husband have three children, two of whom are enrolled in school while the youngest is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Lat H. faces a problem with her farming because she does not have enough animals to hep plow her rice field. Thus, Mrs. Lat H. is requesting a loan to buy another cow to plow the field.

loans.use: To buy another cow to plow the field.

loans.name: Ismatoi

texts.en: Ismatoi R. was born in 1979 in the Asht region of Tajikistan where she still lives today. She is married and has a child. Her husband is in the Russian Federation, so she is raising her child herself. She is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work to ensure her child a good future. She works at the school but the family income depends on their livestock business. Mrs. R. has10 years’ experience in the livestock business. She has a cow and some rams and she dreams of purchasing one more milk cow to start a business selling and producing milk. So she is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $825.00 US to purchase a milk cow..

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Kon

texts.en:
Mrs. Kon N. is a Khmer cake seller in Anlong Tnot Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. Mrs. Kon N. is 47 and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the three others attend school. Her husband, Mr. Khon Pros, is unemployed and assists his wife in making Khmer cakes.

As her business has improved in the past months, Mrs. Kon N. wants to expand her business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to buy more raw materials with which to make more Khmer cakes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make Khmer cakes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase special equipment for handling milk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a cowshed

loans.name: Manzura

texts.en:
Manzura D. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She was brought up in an intelligent family―her father is a doctor and her mother works in the registry office. Mrs. D. is very well educated, and she works at the local rural school. She also participates in her family's livestock business where she helps take care of the animals and also does the milking.

Mrs. D. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $625.00 US so she can purchase one more pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To buy one more pedigreed bull

loans.name: Kumry

texts.en:
Kumry R. has been a client of the MicroInvest since 2008. She is a serious entrepreneur. Mrs.R. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She is married but her husband lives in the Russian Federation. She works on a collective farm and engages in a family business there, but she also makes and sells yarn and warm socks. She dreams of a computerized machine for making yarn.

Mrs.R. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $775.00 US in order to purchase equipment.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Vitaly

texts.en:
Vitaly D. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. MicroInvest has been working with with him since 2008, and he has shown himself to be a serious client. Mr. D. worked on a collective farm, and now has his own livestock business. He has a cow and a bull. From these animals, he makes yarn which he sells along with milk.

Mr. D. is asking KIVA for a business development loan of $775.00 US that will allow him to increase his business income and get married. He wants to purchase one more pedigreed bull.

loans.use: To purchase the one more pedigreed bull

loans.name: Ndiémé

texts.fr:
Ndiémé G., aged 45, is married with four children to look after, and has been a member of the Manguiline Santhiaba Village Bank in Bignona for two years. She wants to boost her business selling fabric, shoes and gold-plated jewelry. She buys supplies in Dakar to sell in Bignona. With her income she contributes to the family expenses and is saving to buy some land. The loan she is requesting will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Ndiémé G., 45 ans, mariée, 04 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Manguiline Santhiaba à Bignona depuis 2 ans. Elle veut renforcer son activité de vente de tissus, chaussures et bijoux en plaqué or. Elle achète à Dakar pour vendre à Bignona. Avec ses revenus elle participe aux charges familiales et épargne pour l’achat d’un terrain. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Business selling fabric, shoes and jewelry

loans.name: Carmelinha Alexandre

texts.en:
Carmelinha is 46 years old and originally from Majacaze in the Gaza Province. Carmelinha is single and has four children: one boy and three girls, one already married.

Carmelinha lived with her parents until 13 years old, when she moved to a Catholic school in the Inhambane Province. In 1976 she dropped out from the school and moved to the capital city Maputo to live with her brother. In Maputo Carmelinha concluded primary school and studied until the 3rd year of the commercial technical school.

In 1980 Carmelinha got married and went to live with her husband in Catembe. When she got divorced in 1986 Carmelinha was already doing some business selling oil and food products. In 1988 she got a job at a manufacturing company in Matola, where she worked until 2000. During that period she hired someone to work at her food stand.

Since 2001 Carmelinha has been dedicating herself to her food stands. She currently has two stands: one located in her backyard and another in one of Catembe’s markets. Carmelinha’s older daughter is helping her with one of the stands. Carmelinha works from 6:30am to 7:00pm and buys all her products in Maputo. During summertime and on weekends Carmelinha reports higher sales. She makes daily sales of MTn 800, but towards the end of the month it can reach MTn 2,000 per day. Carmelinha’s most solid products are potatoes, onions, peanuts, beans and plastic bags. Carmelinha has a cashbook and reports a monthly profit of around MTn 500.

Carmelinha had already asked for previous loans to Hluvuku and has repaid them without problems. Carmelinha is very satisfied with the loans, as it has helped her business improve and her monthly income increase. With this loan of MTn 9,000 Carmelinha intends to buy merchandise such as sugar, beans, butter, peanuts, eggs and soap to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To buy sugar, beans, butter, peanuts, eggs and soap to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr:
Mariama Cissé, aged 42, is married with 10 children in her care, and has been a member of the Manguiline Santhiaba Village Bank in Bignona for five and a half years. She is seeking a loan to run a business selling seasonal fruit (madd fruit and mangoes) that she buys in Bignona and then sells at retail at the bus station. Her income enables her to provide for her family. Mariama is requesting a loan that will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mariama Cissé, 42 ans, Mariée 10 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Manguiline Santhiaba à Bignona depuis 5 ans et demi. Elle veut un prêt pour faire le commerce de fruits saisonniers (madd et mangues) qu’elle achète à Bignona et revend au détail à la gare routière. Ses revenus lui permettent d’entretenir sa famille. Mariama sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Business selling seasonal fruit

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Fatou S., aged 58, is married with three children in her care, and has been a member of the Manguiline Santhiaba Village Bank in Bignona for seven years. She sells fans and pearls that she buys in Ndiassane. Fatou wants to strengthen her business. With her income she provides for herself and contributes towards the family expenses. The loan she is requesting will be repaid after six months in one installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Fatou S., 58 ans, mariée, 03 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Manguiline Santhiaba à Bignona depuis 7 ans. Elle vend des éventails et des perles qu’elle achète à Ndiassane. Fatou veut renforcer son commerce. Avec ses revenus elle se prend en charge et participe aux charges familiales. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Business selling fans and pearls

loans.name: Annet Wani’S Group

texts.en:
Annet W. is a 38-year-old married mother of four children. She also takes care of her brother’s children, all of whom are in school. She lives and works in Kawempe, an urban neighborhood of Kampala.

For the past 10 years, Annet has worked as a tailor, a skill she learned at school and has turned into a profitable business. Using fashion charts that show different styles of clothes, customers come to her shop to select the type of outfit they want, either bringing their own material with them or choosing from the inventory Annet has in stock. In particular, she makes clothes from bitenge, material printed with colorful patterns worn by men and women throughout Uganda. She says it takes her three hours to make a full dress. he number of customers varies from day to day, but December is her busiest month, so much so that she doesn’t have time to eat lunch.

Annet has been a member of MCDT for five years and has paid back four previous loans. Before receiving a loan from MCDT, Annet says it was difficult to get capital for her business. The loans have helped a lot. She will use a new loan to buy more material so that her customers have more to choose from. Although her future is “God’s guess,” she says she would like her business to be larger than it is now.

loans.use: To buy more rolls of fabric

loans.name: Mansata

texts.fr:
Mansata Cissé, aged 44, is married with eight children in her care, and has been a member of the Manguiline Santhiaba Village Bank in Bignona for five and a half years. She wants to strengthen her business of selling fresh fish, juice and ice cream made with monkey bread (the fruit from the baobab tree), sugar, milk powder and roselle. She buys fish in Kafountine to sell in Bignona. Her income enables her to improve the living conditions of her family. Mansata is requesting a loan which will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Mansata Cissé, 44 ans, mariée avec 08 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Manguiline Santhiaba à Bignona depuis 5 ans et demi. Elle veut renforcer son commerce de poisson frais et de jus et crèmes glaces fait à base de pain de singe (fruit du baobab), du sucre, du lait en poudre et du bissap. Elle achète le poisson à Kafountine pour revendre à Bignona. Ses revenus lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Mansata sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Business selling fresh fish, juice and ice cream

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Aminata D., aged 62, is a widow with two children in her care, and has been a member of the Manguiline Santhiaba Village Bank in Bignona for six years. She wants to boost her business, which consists of buying palm oil, lemons and monkey bread (the fruit from the baobab tree) to sell at the market and at home. The income from this business enables her to provide for herself and improve the living conditions of her family. She is requesting a loan that will be repaid after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Aminata D., 62 ans, veuve avec 02 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Manguiline Santhiaba à Bignona depuis 6 ans. Elle veut renforcer son activité qui consiste à acheter de l’huile de palme, du citron et du pain de singe( fruit du baobab) puis revendre au marché et à son domicile. Les revenus tirés de ce commerce lui permettent de se prendre en charge et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: For a business selling produce from the forest

loans.name: Ghulam Ishaq

texts.en:
G. Ishaq, son of G. D., is a 24-year-old young man. He is married and has two children. Because of the war in his home country of Afghanistan during the last 30 years, he could not attend school or continue his limited education, so he has worked instead with his father as a farmer.

Unfortunately, he does not have enough money to buy many seeds and other necessary goods in order to increase his crop yield and to thereby generate greater income for his family. As such, G. Ishaq is seeking a loan in the amount of $650 (30,000 Afghanis) to accomplish this purpose, and he will repay the loan in 24 months.

loans.use: To increase his crop yield by purchasing additional agricultural seeds

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy has been selling babies’ clothes and lingerie in the local market for almost 20 years. She is married with five children. Four of the children are currently in school.

Babies’ clothes have a high demand from women and this has created a more profitable market for sellers. Lucy wants to use the loan to buy more babies’ products like clothes, pomade, soaps, Pampers, diapers and so on, and also to buy lingerie to increase her inventory and sales.

She is a member of the group called Sons of God. Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more bales of babies’ clothes and lingerie.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Theodora is a widow with two children. She has been selling sewing machine parts for almost 38 years in the local market. Business has been sturdy and therefore she wants to use the loan to buy more parts and also to add on sewing materials like polyester, buttons, threads, linen and also polythene bags to increase her income.

Theodora is a member of the group called Sons of God. Members agree in common to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy sewing machine parts

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is married with two children. She used to hawk and sell saucepans but has now decided to add cosmetics to her goods, because they sell faster than the saucepans. Mercy wants to use the loan to buy more cartons of cosmetics to enable her to increase her income to support her family.

She is a member of the group called Sons of God. Members agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy cartons of cosmetics.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en:
Joana is married with six children. She also has three adopted children who are currently living with her.

Joana has been selling hardware for 18 years in the local market. Currently people are putting up buildings and the demand for roofing sheets, paint, nails, door locks and other hardware is very high in her town. She wants to use this loan to buy more hardware to increase her inventory and sales.

Joana is a member of the group called “Abusua Kronkron” meaning Holy Family. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy hardware like roofing sheets, paints, nails, door locks, etc.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 44years and a mother of three children. Her children are currently in school. She sells jewels, lace cloths and other cloths in the local market.

Agnes wants to use this loan to buy more jewels as the demand for jewels from women is very high. She hopes this loan will help her to save for her children’s education. She is a member of the group called Vineyard. Members in the group agree to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy jewelry and lace cloths.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 39 years old and a mother with three children. Two of her children are in school now. Eva loves children so much that she now sells babies’ products like diapers, Pampers, cloths, soaps, creams, washing pans and bowls in the local market.

Eva wants to use this loan to buy more products to increase her inventory and sales as the demand for the products are high. She is a member of the group called God With Us. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more babies’ cloths and products

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana O. lives at Agege in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. She has been in the business of selling underwear, clothes and shoes since 2004. Sales are conducted from a very small kiosk in front of her house. She has been managing her business for the past two years from the small loan she received from LAPO Microfinance. Christiana is 32 years old and is married with two children. The loan of $425 will enable her to buy more clothes and shoes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Stella Mlay's Rengwe Group

texts.en:
Stella M., age 39, is divorced with two children, ages 19 and 10. She has been selling food for six years. She works from 6 a.m. to midnight and is able to make a monthly profit of about $213.

Stella has taken two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to go up-country to buy bananas for sale in Dar es Salaam and to renovate the place where she sells her food. She hopes for a new loan to open a pork butchery business. She will share this loan with her loan group, named Rengwe, whose 16 members guarantee one another in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Stella is third from right in the back row, in a black blouse.

loans.use: To open a pork butchery business

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy O. has been an LAPO member for the past four years. She is 46 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives in Ibatedo in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. Since 1987, her business has been selling cooked food and drinks. Mercy needs the loan amount of $850 to enable her to buy more drinks and food items to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and food items

loans.name: Paullina

texts.en: Paullina O. sells fairly used clothes and bags in her community near Ijaniki in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. She is 41 years old and is a widow with five children. As a widow, things have not been easy for her. Paulina has been in this business since the year 2002; she has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years. She needs a loan of $425 to buy more fairly used clothes and bags to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes and bags

loans.name: Marian

texts.en: Marian A. sells clothes in Ibatedo in the state of Lagos, Nigeria. She has been in this business since 1984 and has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past four years. She is 50 years old and married with two children. Her husband also works to support the family; this reduces the responsibility on Marian and she can focus on her business to attain maximum profit. She is requesting a loan of $850 to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en: Bridget I. is 36 years old and single. She lives in Benin city,  Edo state, Nigeria. Bridget sells cellophane. She has been in this business for the past three years. She is an LAPO client. She needs the loan of $875 to buy more materials for her cellophane business.

loans.use: To buy materials for cellophane sales

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha E. is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in the Oka area of the Edo state in Nigeria. She buys palm kernels and mills them into palm oil. She sells this in the local market in her community. She learned this business over five years. She started her own business in the year 2002. She needs a loan of $700 to buy more palm kernels for milling into palm oil to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more palm kernels

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence O. is 48 years old, married, and has five children. She lives in Benin City, in the state of Edo in Nigeria. Her business, which she has been in for five years, is selling frozen fish to people in her community and also to market women. Florence needs a loan of $875 to buy more fish to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish to sell

loans.name: Florencia Augusto

texts.en:
Florencia is 49 years old and originally from Maxaquene neighborhood in the capital city Maputo. She is divorced and the mother of two boys, both working in South Africa.

Florencia lived with her parents until 12 years old, when they got divorced and she moved with her mother and brothers to her grandparents’ house. Florencia only studied until 8th grade. Due to her family’s difficult financial situation she had to start working quite young, getting a job as a house maid at 16 years old. When Florencia was 18 years old she got pregnant and went to live with her husband. A few years later Florencia got divorced and moved back to her mother’s house.

In 1998 Florencia started to sell sandwiches and juices in her neighborhood and liked the commerce business. In 2002 some friends invited her to go to South Africa to buy products to sell in Mozambique. She first started selling clothes and then changed to food products.

Florencia works at this until today. She goes to South Africa once or twice per month and together with friends rents a car and brings the products to Mozambique. Florencia does not have a store; she provides the merchandise to some stores (such as the one in the picture) and uses her house as a warehouse to stock merchandise. Florencia has a monthly income of approximately MTn 40,000 and reports that the most lucrative periods are the weekends. Her most wanted products are eggs, potatoes, onions and tomatoes. Florencia has three employees who help her deliver the merchandise and collect payment: two women who are married and have children who Florencia pays MTn 1,700 monthly and one young man who she pays MTn 1,300 monthly. Florencia has a monthly profit of around MTn 8,500 that she uses to support her family (including parents and some siblings).

This will be Florencia’s first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. With the MTn 13,000 loan she intends to buy merchandise in South Africa and increase her stock. In the future Florencia would like to buy her own car to help transport goods from South Africa and also to build a small henhouse at her backyard to raise chickens.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Comité San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
The "San Cayetano" Committee is formed by neighbors of the neighborhood of Villa Bonita of the city of Villa Elisa. This is one of the committees that is well organized and is stable. Even though they are only in their fourth cycle, during this time the have displayed the ability to together.

All of the members are working mothers. All of them have their own activities and some of them have full time jobs, in which case they perform their activity during their free time in order to earn extra money. The committee members get along very well and they have shown their unity in several occasions, whether working together in different activities or solving any problems.

The loans received from the Fundación Paraguaya were invested in the purchase of a variety of articles, the majority of them materials and merchandise for the businesses of the members. Some of these products are: meats, drinks, rice, noodles, etc. These products were purchased by the members that have small grocery stores and such. The members that have other types of businesses, such as the manufacture of cleaning products, sawing, etc. used their loans to buy the materials to make their products. These products are: fabric, thread, chemical products, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

El Comité “San Cayetano” se formó a partir de la unión de vecinas del barrio Villa Bonita de la ciudad de Villa Elisa, éste es uno de los comités que ha logrado una buena organización y estabilidad en dicha ciudad, si bien solamente están con el cuarto ciclo, en este tiempo han demostrado bastante capacidad.

Todas las integrantes del comité son madres y trabajadoras. Todas las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias, aunque algunas tienen trabajos formales, desarrollan sus emprendimientos en un tiempo extra para acrecentar sus ingresos. El comité lleva la mas armoniosa relación entre todas sus miembros y han demostrado su unidad en varias ocasiones, ya sea desarrollando actividades en forma conjunta, como solucionando cualquier inconveniente siempre bajo la decisión de la mayoría.

Los créditos recibidos de la Fundación Paraguaya fueron invertidos en la compra de varios artículos, la mayoría de ellos, materia prima o productos de mercancía para las actividades de las integrantes del comité. Algunos de estos artículos son: carnes, bebidas, arroz, pastas, etc.; estos artículos fueron comprados generalmente por las señoras que se dedican a su comercialización, o sea las que tienen despensa, casilla, etc., mientras que las otras personas dedicadas a otros rubros ( fabricación de productos de limpieza, costureras, etc.) utilizaron su crédito para la compra de materia prima para su actividad: hilos, telas, productos químicos, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of materials  and merchandise for their different businesses.

loans.name: Maria Helena

texts.en:
Maria Helena is 45 years old and originally from Moamba District in the Maputo Province. She is divorced and has three sons: two are working in South Africa and one is living with her in the capital city Maputo and has just concluded high school.

Maria Helena was raised by her grandparents. She studied until 7th grade and stopped due to her family’s difficult financial situation. Maria Helena started to work quite young: at 17 years old she got a job at an agriculture company, where she worked for four years. For some years Maria Helena worked at a small stand in the street selling basic needs products to help support her children. In 1999 she started to go to South Africa to buy products to sell in Mozambique. She first started selling cooking oil, but then changed to plastic bags and chicken paws.

The most productive selling period is between April and October. Her monthly profit is around MTn 4,000, and Maria Helena uses this money to support her family, including her younger son’s education. Maria Helena does not have a store, she delivers the merchandise to her clients' houses or stores.

This will be Maria Helena’s second loan with Hluvuku. The first loan of MTn 10,000 was used to buy merchandise in South Africa and Maria Helena paid it back without difficulties. This MTn 16,000 loan will also be used to increase inventory, more specifically to buy plastic bags and chicken paws.

In the future Maria Helena would like to build a small market where she would be able to sell her products and even diversify the products brought from South Africa.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome C. lives in Araromin in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. She has been in the business of selling foodstuffs and green leaves for the past 23 years. Salome, who is 45 years old, married and has ten children, has been an LAPO member for the past four years. She is in need of a loan of $600 to buy more foodstuffs to sell. This, she said, will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A.'s determination is evident as she uses one grinding machine to care for herself and to support her husband and her home. She is 56 years old, and she has seven children. She grinds peppers, tomatoes and beans. Mary needs a loan of $350 to buy another grinding machine so that she can meet the increasing demands of her numerous customers. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy one grinding machine

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria A. is 67 years old. She is married and has five children. She hails from Adeloko in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. Maria sells foodstuffs and has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years. Her loan request of $350 will be used to buy more foodstuffs for her business. Maria thanks all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Leticia

texts.es:
Leticia is a loving mother and grandmother with a mind for business, and she has been ever since she had her beloved children. She took on various businesses including sales through catalogues and she created beautiful pieces of art by hand. And most recently, with the support of her children, she has dedicated her time to remodel a small area of her home to create an internet cafe. These communication and information services are helping many people in the city, but the small space is not enough to meet the demands of her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Leticia, es madre y abuela amorosa y emprendedora, desde que les concedió el don de vida a sus queridos hijos. Se dedicó a diferentes actividades, a la venta por campañas, realizaba hermosos trabajos manuales y finalmente con el apoyo de sus hijos decidió adecuar un pequeño espacio de su domicilio para abrir un locutorio y brindar servicios de internet, estos servicios de información y comunicación que brinda están ayudando a mucha gente en su ciudad, sin embargo esto no es suficiente para resolver la demanda y exigencia de sus clientes.

loans.use: To remodel her work space.

loans.name: Agossou

texts.fr:
Mr. Agossou A. was born February 29th, 1976 in Lomé. He is single and taking care of a child. In 1999 he established a store selling spare parts in Adawlato neighborhood of Lomé. He imports replacement parts from Germany and Nigeria. He is a major supplier of motor oil, batteries, belts, and other parts. His main customers are specialized and four-wheel drive mechanics. Currently stocks of certain parts have fallen noticeably and for this reason Mr. Agossou A. is seeking his first loan to buy 50 oil filters, 11 belts, 20 spark plugs, and batteries. With this new stock, he will be able to satisfy his customers and in turn make a good profit.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur A. Agossou est né le 29 février 1976 à Lomé. Il est célibataire avec un enfant à charge. Depuis 1999 il a crée un magasin de vente des pièces détachées dans le quartier de Adawlato à Lomé. Il importe les pièces de rechange de l’Allemagne et du Nigeria. Il est un grand fournisseur d’huile à moteur de batterie, de courroie et d’autres pièces de rechange. Ses principaux clients sont les mécaniciens à quatre roues et les particuliers. Présentement les stocks de certains pièces ont subi une diminution sensible raison pour laquelle Monsieur A. Agossou sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter cinquante (50) filtres à huile, onze (11) courroies, 20 paquets de bougie d’allumage et des batteries. Ainsi avec ce nouveau stock, il pourra satisfaire ces clients et en retour dégager un bon bénéfice.

loans.use: Purchase of replacement parts

loans.name: Kossiwa

texts.fr:
Mrs. Kossiwa K. was born December 31st, 1964 in Aného, a town in Togo. She is married and the mother of seven children. She is a retailer of smoked fish, vegetables, and seasonings. She has been doing business since 2002 and many of her customers are from her neighborhood. During this, the rainy season, when food prices are increasing, her own capital doesn’t allow her to purchase goods like she used to. For this reason, she is seeking a 250,000 Franc CFA loan to buy 22 baskets of smoked fish, four baskets of vegetables, and three baskets of red peppers. With the income her business brings her, she helps her husband with the family’s expenses.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame K. Kossiwa est née le 31 décembre 1964 à Aného, une des villes du Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de sept (7) enfants. Elle est revendeuse de poissons fumés, de légumes et des condiments. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 2002 et a beaucoup de clients qui viennent de son quartier. En cette période de pluie où le prix des denrées alimentaires augmente, son fonds propre seul ne lui permet plus de pouvoir effectuer des achats comme elle le faisait par le passé. A cet effet, elle sollicite un crédit de 250.000 FCFA pour acheter 22 paniers de poissons fumés, 4 paniers de légumes et 3 paniers de piments rouge. Avec le revenu que cette activité lui procure, elle aide son mari dans les dépenses familiales.

loans.use: Retail of fish and vegetables

loans.name: Kpatanyo

texts.fr:
Mrs. Kpatanyo A. was born November 27th, 1968 in Afagna-Bléta. She is married and the mother of two children. Since 1999, she has been doing business in charcoal, corn, and in 2004 she also began selling cell phone credit recharge cards. Her retail of charcoal and corn consists of buying from distant farms and reselling to dealers in Lomé. She has already benefited from one loan through WAGES and successfully repaid it. The second loan that she is seeking will allow her to buy 20 bags of corn and 40 bags of charcoal.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame A. Kpatanyo est née le 27 novembre 1968 à Afagna-Bléta. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Depuis 1999, elle exerce le commerce de charbon de bois, de maïs et en 2004 elle a ajouté la vente des cartes de recharge. Son activité de vente de charbon et de maïs consiste à acheter dans les fermes reculées et de les revendre aux détaillants à Lomé. Elle a une fois bénéficié d’un crédit au près de WAGES et a bien remboursé. Le second crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter vingt (20) sacs de maïs et quarante (40) sacs de charbon de bois.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal and corn

loans.name: Alvaro Alfredo

texts.en:
Alvaro is 54 years old and originally from Alto Molocue, a district in the Zambezia Province. Alvaro is married and has seven people under his responsibility.

Alvaro was raised by his parents until he was 14 years old, when he moved to Maputo to continue his studies at the Seminario Sagrado Coracao de Jesus. Since 1975 Alvaro has been working at the Maritime Administration of Maputo, hence all his experience is in the fishing business.

Alvaro decided to start his fishing business in 2000 after the severe flood that happened in Mozambique and destroyed many businesses. He is currently working at the Macaneta region in the Catembe district, a village 10 minutes' ferry boat ride away from the capital city of Maputo. Alvaro has one employee who coordinates all the work with other temporary workers and fishermen.

With his first Kiva loan of MTn 25,000 Alvaro intends to buy fishing nets, water wings and weights to improve his business, allowing him to diversify his fishing operations.

In the future Alvaro would like to buy another boat to use for tourism, as he considers the market very attractive.

loans.use: To buy materials to improve his fishing business.

loans.name: Luisa Eugenio

texts.en:
Luisa is 43 years old and originally from the capital city Maputo. She is married and has two children, both attending school. On top of her children, Luisa also supports her parents who live with her and four nieces who Luisa sends money and food each month.

Luisa grew up with her parents. She studied until 6th grade and stopped in 1983 in order to go to nursing technical school. Since 1991 Luisa has worked as a nurse at the Jose Macamo Hospital, working at different shifts five days per week. With her monthly salary Luisa is able to save around MTn 500 per month to cover any emergency the family may have. Luisa is also back at school, currently studying at 8th grade during the nights, from 6:00pm to 10:00pm daily.

This will be Luisa’s first loan with Hluvuku and Kiva. With the MTn 12,000 loan Luisa intends to buy sanitary vase, a sink and other things to finish building her bathroom. Luisa already had a loan from former Banco Austral (now Barclays), which she also used to build the bathroom, buying aluminum roofing and cement. That loan she had to pay back all at once and they were not flexible in terms of the value and number of installments.

In the future Luisa would like to finish high school and learn how to drive, getting a drivers’ license. Her dream is to one day driver her own car.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her house.

loans.name: Helena Leta

texts.en:
Helena is 42 years old and originally from the capital city Maputo. Helena has five children, of which three are studying. Helena’s older daughter is at home and one of her sons lost his place at school, so will have to wait until next year.

Helena was raised by her mother who worked as a house maid. She studied until 2nd grade and stopped due to her mother’s difficult financial situation. Once her father abandoned her mother, Helena was taken to live with her grandmother and then with an aunt who was also a house maid.

Helena started to sell basic needs products for her aunt when she was a child. In 1981 she started to sell products at her own stand. Today Helena’s most profitable products are peanuts, beans and cereals. Helena works all day long, as the stand is located in front of her house. She is currently negotiating a stand at the Benfica market where she will have more customers and increase her daily income. Today Helena has a daily profit of MTn 75 (around US$3.00) and also has an income coming from three rooms she rents at a house she built next to her own.

Through a neighbor Helena heard about Hluvuku and decided to ask for her first loan of MTn 10,000 in order to strengthen her business. Helena will buy merchandise in bulk, reducing the price of acquisition and consequently increasing her profit.

In the future Helena would like to open her own general store, with legal license to operate and with many customers, so she can increase her income.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Ana Dela

texts.es:
Mi name is Ana Dela B. C. and I am 32 years old. I am a merchant and I live in San Pedro Sacatepéquez. I earn a living selling traditional women's clothing. I launched my business 15 years ago, with a capital of Q.500.00. As time went by I started to get new clients and I am now selling in different towns and villages where I offer my products on the streets. About 6 years ago, my sister introduced the idea of also selling beauty products through catalogs. Since I already had a good number of clients, the products we well received.

Thanks to the Lord people have been ordering clothing and beauty products, therefore I am in need of more capital to be able to fulfill their orders. Now that everything has gone up in price one needs to invest more in the merchandise, especially if one wants to have the items clients request readily available. My goal with this loan is to be able to take advantage of the season, in which people request large orders, due to the town celebrations that are soon to come.

I always work hard to get ahead and take good care of my two children, especially now that I don't live with my husband.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Soy AnaDela B. C., tengo 32 años soy comerciante y vivo en San Pedro Sacatepèquez. Me dedico a la venta de ropa típica para mujeres, inicie desde hace 15 años, inicié con un capital de Q. 500.00, conforme fue pasando el tiempo empecé a ganar nuevos clientes y estoy vendiendo en diferentes pueblos y aldeas en donde ofrezco mi producto de forma ambulante. Hace unos 6 años mi hermana me propuso poder vender también productos de belleza por catalogo, y como yo ya tenia buen número de clientes fue bien aceptado por las personas que yo les ofreciera otros productos. Gracias a Dios, la gente me hace pedidos de ropa y productos, por lo que yo necesito más capital para poder cumplir con ellos ya que como todo se ha encarecido uno necesita invertir más en la mercadería, y tener siempre lo que los clientes piden, mis metas son que con este crédito pueda aprovechar esta temporada en la que siempre las personas hacen buen pedido por las fiestas de los pueblos que están próximas. Siempre hago mi mejor esfuerzo para salir adelante y mantener bien a mis hijos ya que no vivo con mi esposo por lo que tengo que velar por mis 2 niños.

loans.use: Merchandise Purchase

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
Mi name is Juliana B. C. and I am 44 years old. I earn a living selling traditional clothing and products through catalogs in San Pedro Sacatepéquez, San Juan Sacatepéquez and surrounding areas.

I stared selling when I was 10 years old to help my mother, since I had several brothers and sisters. As time went by I learned a lot about sales and how to win clients. Currently I also do traditional embroidery, blouses, change purses and I also sell firewood.

Life has taught me to take advantage of all the opportunities that have come my way. In this occasion I need capital to have the products my clients request the most readily available and also the products I sell to other vendors.

I've worked very hard to be able to get ahead, and now that I no longer live with my husband I've only worked so that my daughters can get an education and are able to be professionals. It is my wish that they have a more comfortable job than mine.

At the present time I have several pending orders and I like to be punctual with my clients. Thank God that people actually look for me and know me. This is the reason why I want to take advantage of this opportunity and be able to expand my business.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

Mi nombre es Juliana B. C. tengo 44 años de edad, me dedico a la venta de ropa típica, venta de productos por catálogo, de forma ambulante en San Pedro Sacatepèquez y San Juan Sacatepèquez, y sus aldeas. Desde que tenía 10 años empecé a vender para ayudar a mi mamá ya que éramos varios hermanos y hermanas, conforme fue pasando el tiempo aprendí mucho a como vender y ganar clientes, también hago bordados de cortes típicos, blusas, monederos, y tengo venta de leña. La vida me ha enseñado a aprovechar todas las oportunidades que tengo y en esta ocasión necesito más capital para poder tener en existencia el producto que las señoras me piden, ya que también le surto producto a otra vendedoras, he trabajado muy duro para poder salir adelante y ya que no vivo con mi esposo, yo solo he trabajado duro para que mis hijas estudiaran y que puedan tener una carrera profesional, ya que es mi deseo que tengan un trabajo más cómodo que el mío. Actualmente tengo varios pedidos que tengo que entregar y me gusta cumplir con mis clientes, gracias a Dios la gente me busca y me conoce por eso quiero aprovechar perfectamente esta oportunidad para agrandar más el negocio y poder surtir en mi casa a los clientes que me visiten.

loans.use: Purchase of traditional merchandise and catalog products

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Genara

texts.es:
Genera is a producer of milk. Her product is sold to the Delicia company (a company that makes icecream). She also farms a small plantation. She is married and her husband works in Argentina as a tailor. They have four children. They live in the Palomar community (two and a half hours from the city of La Paz).

The funds from the loan will be invested in purchasing a cow with the purpose of increasing the production of milk to generate a greater income.

This is her first credit throught Impro. The assessment conducted qualified her for the approval of the requested loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Genara es productora de leche de vaca, su producto es comercializado a la empresa Delicia (compañía productora de helados). Asimismo, se desenvuelve como pequeña agricultora de hortalizas, tiene un esposo el cual trabaja en la República de Argentina como costurero y unos cuatro hijos. Su domicilio es en la comunidad de Palomar (a dos horas y media de la Ciudad de La Paz). El monto del crédito será invertido en la compra de una vaca de mediana calidad, el propósito es incrementar su producción de leche y generar mayores ingresos económicos. Este es su primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Amalia

texts.es:
Amalia is a procuder of milk. Her product is sold to the Delicia company (one that produces icrecream and other milk products). She also spends her time harvesting along-side her daughter. The harvest is sold in the city of La Paz. Her husband is an elderly person but he helps her harvest the fields. The family lives in the Palomar community (two and a half hours from La Paz).

The purchase of a mature cow is the reason for her loan request. The purpose is to increase the milk production and generate a greater income.

This is her first loan through Impro. Her assessment was favorable and has permitted us to approver her for the loan requested.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Amalia es productora de leche de vaca, su producto es vendido a la empresa Delicia (fábrica de helados y otros productos lácteos), igualmente ocupa su tiempo en la cosecha de hortalizas junto a su hija, las cuales son vendidas en la ciudad de La Paz. Su esposo es una persona de la tercera edad por lo que ayuda en el trabajo de campo. La familia vive en la Comunidad de Palomar (a dos horas y media de La Paz). La compra de una vaca de mediana edad es la razón de su solicitud de crédito, el propósito es incrementar su producción de leche y generar mayores ingresos económicos. Este es su primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada nos permite aprobar satisfactoriamente el préstamo solicitado por Amalia.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
Jorge is a taxi driver in the city of La Paz and it is his primary source of income, covering the needs of his three children (one attending the state university, another is in school, and the last suffers from a mental illness). The family lives in the city of La Paz in the Alto Tejar region.

His loan request is to change his car. The car he currently depends on is in a state of disrepair an it doesn't permit him to work without interruption.

This is his fourth loan through Impro. His previous assessment was favorable.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Jorge es transportista de servicio público (conductor de taxi) en la ciudad La Paz, es su principal fuente de ingreso, la cuál cubre la manutención de sus tres hijos (uno asiste a la universidad estatal, otra al colegio y la última sufre de una enfermedad mental). La familia vive en la Ciudad de La Paz Zona Alto Tejar.
