By working directly with suppliers, Alisher is able to offer highly competitive prices to his customers.  He now wants to increase his inventory by importing more goods at a time, and has therefore requested a loan of $1,200 for ten months.

loans.use: To import larger quantities of goods.

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech P. lives in Or Rumchang Village, Pursat Province, Cambodia. She is married and has two children. She makes around $1.50 per day making khmer noodles. Her husband, Mr. Khum Samon, 35, is a farmer who makes around $1.50 per day. All of their children are young and attend school.

She seeks a loan to purchase a noodle-making machine for her business. This loan will help to increase her income and improve her business conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a noodle-making machine for her business

loans.name: Sitha Meth Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitha M. is the leader of a four-person business group in Kampong Tralanh Krom Village in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is 50 years old and she sells fish. Previously, Mrs. Sitha M. obtained a loan to start her business. Her business has improved and she needs to expand it, but she does not have enough money to purchase more fish to sell in the local market. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

Her husband, Mr. Pach Khon, is a subsistence farmer. Mrs. Sitha M. has a child who goes to work in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell in the local market.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 50 year-old Asha S.. She is married, and has four children aged between 26 and 34. In 2002, Asha established her traditional African cloth business. Asha requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of African cloth in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility, as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-credit worthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase the additional stock of traditional cloth.

loans.name: Asnati

texts.en:
Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 49 year-old Asinati Shemahombe. She is married, and has six children aged between 15 and 25. She has three dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2003, Asinati established her café business. Asinati requires a loan in order to purchase additional ingredients, such as rice, beans, cooking oil and sugar, as well as utensils. She thanks you for your support.

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.name: Tiba

texts.en: Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39 year-old Tiba Nasoro.  She is widowed, and has two children ages 10 and 15. In 2006, Tiba established her bar business. Tiba has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stock including beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support. Tiba's bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’  (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Kikelomo

texts.en:
Kikelomo I. sells yams, sweet potatoes, bananas and plantain in Okoko market. She comes to her shop on Mondays through Saturdays at 7am and stays until night fall, selling her goods to her customers. She is 40 years old and is married with 5 children.

Kikelomo has the ambition to expand her business by buying more yams, sweet potatoes, bananas and plantain with the loan of $700 that she is requesting. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years. She lives in Okoko, Lagos state, Nigeria, close to the market and, with a larger inventory, she will be able to satisfy her customers more fully. She says thanks to Kiva and her lenders.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell.

loans.name: Omowumi

texts.en:
During a visit to A., it was discovered that she has a small kiosk where she sells cosmetics. Although the kiosk is small according to her, the business is moving and booming. “I have been managing the little loan that I borrowed from LAPO Microfinance to sustain my business," she said. She acquired the skill over 3 years and she has been in this business since the year 2000. She is 34 years old and she is married with 4 children. She has been a leader in a lending group for the past 5 years.

A. needs the sum of $700 to buy more cosmetics so that she can expand her business, thereby increasing her profit margin. She remains grateful to Kiva and LAPO Microfinance for their financial support.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy U. is a petty trader who sells foodstuffs at Igbelerin community in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has been in this business since 1998. Her shop is scanty because she doesn’t have enough capital to make it bigger, although she has been borrowing a little capital from LAPO Microfinance for the past 2 years.  She is now soliciting a loan of $425 to buy more foodstuffs so that she can enlarge her business and increase her profit margin. Joy is business oriented and she has the desire to travel to central Lagos to buy more crayfish in large quantities to supply her fellow small-scale retailers. Joy is 38 years old and married with 2 children. She is thankful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy wholesale inventory

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 51 year-old Ester N.. She is married, and has four children between ages 20 and 30. She has 2 dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2006, Ester established her poultry business. Ester requires a loan in order to purchase additional chicks and feed. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku. Who or what are ‘kuku’, you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. Firstly, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiple naturally! Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and feed.

During those years, he has faced numerous financial problems because he generates very little income and, as a result, he has not been able to solve all of his family's problems. Now, he is hoping to increase the products he sells for a profit by buying more livestock in order to raise the current level of his income. Therefore, he is requesting a loan in the amount of $875 (40,000 Afghanis), and he promises to repay the loan in 24 months.

texts.en: Adenike A. lives in the town of Issashi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She makes a living selling different types of plastic items, such as jugs, baskets, one-gallons containers and plate racks. She studied this business for a year before opening her shop in 1995. Adenike is 45 years old, married and has three children. She has been a client of LAPO Microfinance for the past three years. Adenike has applied for a new loan of $850 to buy more plastic items to sell, and wants to express her thanks to Kiva and her lenders.

loans.use: To buy more plastic items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Thomasi

texts.en:
Thomasi is a 34-year-old resident of Chanika in Dar Es Salaam. He has been in business for the past five years operating a shop selling Lake Victoria smoked fish and other food items.
He is now in need of a loan to help expand his business.

loans.use: To expand the business.

loans.name: Banco Maranatha Group

texts.en:
Viercelie is an intelligent, 35-year-old woman. She lives with her three children and her husband Wilmer in the community of Los Algodores. With this loan she will start a small business selling clothing in her community. She plans on selling them to her friends from her house and on the street. Her favorite food is rice, and when she is not working she enjoys watching news on the TV.

In addition to helping Viercelie's business, this loan will be used to fund the businesses of each of the group members. These 10 entrepreneurs are being added to a large community of women that already have loans from Esperanza. We are excited to see them flourish and become a strong part of this community.

Thank you for your support and generosity!

loans.use: To buy a supply of clothing.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Titos Paulo

texts.pt:
Titos is 28 years old and was born in Namaacha. He is single, and has a 5-year-old daughter who lives with her mother and is in school. Titos finances the schooling of his 5 nieces and nephews, sending them money on a monthly basis. They live with their mother, however their father lost his life last year (2007).

Titos is a teacher, and has the equivalent of a 12th grade education. He has been working as a teacher for five years, earning a salary of 4,500.00 MT a month. Because of his expenses with his nieces and nephews he is not able to save any money.

Titos lives in his own house, which he intends to improve with this loan. It is his dream to finish and furnish the house.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva volunteer.

Nome: Titos paulo R. Localizaçao : namaacha Sector de Actividade: Habitaçao Uso do emprestimo: Compra de material de construçao Data de Desembolso: 05-05-08 Valor de emprestimo: 10.000,00mt Numero de prestaçoes: 16

Titos de 28 anos de idade, natural de namaacha, solteiro pai de uma filha de 5 anos e frequenta colegeo, vive com a sua mae e custea estudos de 5 sobrinhos enviando mensalmente dinheira para casa onde eles vive com a sua mae, sao filhos do tio que perdeu a vida no ano passado (2007).

Titos tem a formaçao de professor, com nivel equivalente a 12ªclasse, assim trabalha como professor a cinco anos, aufere um salario mensal de 4.500,00mt, diz que nao consegue poupar nenhum dinheiro devido as despesas dos sobrinhos.

Titos vive numa propria casa, aqual pretende melhorar com este emprestimo, constitui grande sonho para a vida dele concluir a casa de material convencional e mobilar.

loans.use: To buy materials to build family's house

loans.name: Reginaldo Elias

texts.pt:
Reginaldo is 33 years old and was born in Inhambane. He is separated and lives with his 3 children and 2 brothers. His children are 10, 8, and 3 months. He had the first two with his ex-wife and the last one with his girlfriend. The two older children are already in school.

Reginaldo concluded training to be an elementary schoolteacher and has taught for 8 years. He began in the district of Magude, and in 1993 he was transferred to Mugado primary school located in on the border of Swaziland in the district of Namaacha. There he works from 7:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and then 1:30 p.m. to 5:30 p.m. His monthly salary is 3,276.00 MT, from which he is able to save 500.00 MT per month.

This is Reginaldo’s second loan with Hluvuku and his first one with Kiva. The first loan was 1,000.00 MT, which he used to buy material needed to add on to his house. Due to the cost of living, he has had to build the addition in phases, which is why he is taking out a second loan.

Reginaldo is confident that he can pay off his loan before the final due date. In the future he hopes to take out another loan to furnish his house and re-open his small business establishment in order to increase his family’s income, because he plans on marrying his girlfriend soon.

Translated from Portuguese by Jill Haring, Kiva volunteer.

Reginaldo tem 33 anos de idade, nasceu em inhambane, é separado e vive com os seus tres filhos e dois irmaos ,(Filhos)sendo um de 10 anos de idade, outra de 8 anos e ultimo com tres meses de idade, dizer que os primeiros dois fez com a sua ex-esposa e ultimo com a namorada, os dois maior já estudam.

Reginaldo concluiu a formaçao de professores primarios e trabalha como professor durane 8 anos, começa a trabalhar no distrito de magude e 1993 foi transferido para distrito de namaacha na vila fronteriço com Swazilandia na escola primaria Mugado onde entra das 7:30h – 12:30h periodo de manha e das 13:30—17:30h, tem um salario mensal de 3.276,00mt reginaldo depois das despesas consegue poupar mensalmente 500,00mt.

Este é o segundo emprestimo de reginaldo na balcao da Hluvuku e o primeiro com kiva, o primeiro foi de 10000,00mt e foi usado para compra de material para ampliaçao da sua casa e devido ao custo de vida está ampiando em fase, onde este tambem será empreque nesta mesma casa, futuramente reginaldo, apois a conclusao do pagamaneto que está confiante em liquidar antes do prazo fixado, pretende solicitar outro emprestimo para comprar mobilia e reabrir a seu pequeno estabelecimento comercial para aumentar a renda familia pois pretende casar brevemente com a sua namorada e ja que assim o agregado familiar vai aumentar.

loans.use: To buy materials to build family's house

loans.name: Fatuma Namagembe's Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is the leader of a five-member group. She is 28 years old and married, with five children. They range in age from 6 to 17. All of them are still in school. The community she lives and works in is semi-urban.

She has been selling charcoal and water and operating a salon for the last seven years. She purchases charcoal from roving vendors in vehicles. She has a semi-permanent wooden structure by the roadside in Kawaala, a very busy trading center just outside Kampala, where she displays the sacks and sells full sacks and small amounts. The salon is also nearby. She sells tap water but has a big tank in which she catches rain water for sale. There is a market for what she does.

Her main challenges include high transport costs, which are embedded in the high wholesale prices, thieves, and flooding that limits clients' movements. The charcoal also gets wet when it rains.

She also has been able to construct three rental rooms, which greatly contribute to the family welfare.

She plans to open a retail shop, construct more rooms for renting out and acquire another water tank. Fatuma has successfully paid back more than ten loans.

loans.use: To increase her stock of products

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kudiratu

texts.en: Kudiratu O. lives in the town of Okoko in Lagos State, Nigeria. For the last four years she has made a living selling chin- chin, a popular local snack. Kudiratu is 38 years old and married with four children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the last four years, and has applied for a new loan for $700 to buy more flour so that she can bake chin-chin in large enough quantities to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy flour for baking chin-chin, a snack made from flour

loans.name: El Arroyo Unidad Group

texts.en:
Martina E. H. is a middle-aged woman that lives in Samaná, Dominican Republic. As a single mother, her small vending business allows her to support her two sons. With this particular loan, she is looking forward to the possibility of acquiring more inventory such as necklaces, purses, and jewelry. The earnings from her business will allow her to continue to support her children and put her one step closer to her dream, which is to return to school and earn a degree.

Martina (pictured in the center with the brown shirt) is just one member of the 10 person bank, El Arroyo Unido. Together, these Dominican entrepreneurs are able unite in solidarity, allowing them access to funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. The concept of this group bank paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the other members gladly help cover one another’s payments in order to receive their next loan together.

On behalf of Martina E. and the entire team at Esperanza, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty that you are making a difference in.

loans.use: To increase her inventory of jewelry, key chains, purses, and other small items

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ikenkechukwu

texts.en: Ikenkechukwu U. is 29 years old and married with no children. He runs a shop where he sells food. He also has a motorcycle, which he uses for transportation. Ikenkechukwu studied his trade for five and half years before opening his shop five years ago. He has applied for a loan of $1,200 to buy more food to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Tarana

texts.en: Tarana M. is a 22-year-old woman who has bred sheep in the Bilasuvar region since 2003. She raises and sells the sheep to local bazaar traders and local people. A meal of mutton is especially popular at summer wedding parties. She lives with her husband and daughter, and her husband's parents. All the members of her family are unemployed and it is very hard to cover their basic needs. Tarana has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase ten sheep ($60 each) and fodder ($200). She believes that during the wedding season she could sell many sheep, the sales of which will enable her to purchase more sheep.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sheep and fodder.

loans.name: Zamiq

texts.en: Zamiq G. is a 27-year-old farmer who breeds sheep in the Bilasuvar region. He has nine years of experience in this field. He lives with his family in the Internally Displaced People Settlement and his life conditions are below the poverty line. Zamiq has borrowed funds previously and has successfully repaid the loan. With his first loan, he purchased five sheep to breed and sell in the local bazaar. He spent the money he earned from the first loan improving quality of life conditions for his family. He plans to use this second loan of $800 USD to purchase 10 sheep ($60 USD each) and fodder.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sheep and fodder.

loans.name: Hijran

texts.en: Hijran M. is a 46-year-old woman who sells milk and dairy products to local people and milk factory. She started her business in 1989. She is married and has three children. They have all lived together in the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement since 1993. Their life conditions improved with the first loan that Hijran borrowed form Aqroinvest four years ago. With that loan she purchased her milk cow and earned money. She successfully repaid her first loan. As she and her husband are unemployed, the dairy business is their family's sole source of income. Now Hijran would like to improve her family's life conditions again and for this purpose she has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase one milk cow.

loans.use: To purchase one milk cow.

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en: Khatira Q. is a 32-year-old woman who has bred calves for meat production since 1989. She lives with her family in the southern part of Azerbaijan, Bilasuvar region. She would like to expand her activity and purchase more calves. Summer is the high season for weddings, which offers the potential for increased sales of meat. As well, meat is very popular all across Azerbaijan. Khatira has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase two calves (each for $300 USD) and fodder for the rest of the $200 USD.

loans.use: Going to purchase two calves and fodder.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Aqroinvest Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en: Yashar M. is a 42-year-old farmer who owns a dairy business in the southern region of the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement. He has ten years of experience in this field. Because dairy products, including milk, are very popular all across Azerbaijan and Azerbaijani people use them in their everyday life, Yashar wants to expand his business. He works in the Bilasuvar Executions Department of the Azerbaijan Republic, but the salary he receives is very low and not enough to cover his family's needs. He would like to purchase one more cow and increase his dairy selling business. For this purpose he has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase one milk cow.

loans.use: To purchase one milk cow.

loans.name: Mujeres De Fe En Cristo Group

texts.en:
J. is a single 40-year-old mother of three beautiful children. Her motivation in life is to provide a good life for her children, and to send them all to a good school. With this loan she will begin selling used clothing. She plans on traveling to the bigger city of Santiago to purchase everything and then will sell it in her community for a small profit. She hopes that one day she will have a house of her own, and will be able to live in a safe part of town. Her favorite foods are plantains with meat, and in her free time she likes reading her Bible.

Note: This is a group loan. In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Thank you for supporting this group of entrepreneurs, and God Bless!

loans.use: To buy used clothing for retail.

loans.name: Khagani

texts.en: Khagani M. is a 38-year-old man who has raised sheep to sell as mutton since 1997. He raises sheep and than sells them to the local bazaar traders. He lives in the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement. He has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase more sheep and increase his income. He will use this loan to purchase 10 sheep and fodder.

loans.use: Going to purchase 10 sheep and fodder.

loans.name: Vali

texts.en: Vali A. is a 47-year-old farmer whose main activity for many years has been calf breeding for meat production. He is married and has three children. Vali lives in the southern region of Bilasuvar. Meat is very popular across Azerbaijan and people use it in their everyday cuisine. To expand his business, Vali has applied for a loan of $800 USD to purchase two calves for an estimated $400 USD each.

loans.use: Going to purchase two calves.

loans.name: Nulu Kizza's Group

texts.en:
Nulu is the leader of a five-member group. She is 38 years old and married, with four children. They range in age from 10 to 17. All of them are still in school. The community she lives and works in is semi-urban, with a nearby slum in a wetland. The surrounding area is prone to flooding in the rainy season.

For more than 10 years she has been selling charcoal, which she purchases from roving vendors in vehicles. She has a semi-permanent structure where she displays the sacks and sells full sacks and small amounts.

Her main challenges include high transport costs, which are embedded in the high wholesale prices, thieves, flooding that limits her clients' movements, and rain that soaks the charcoal. No one is interested in buying wet charcoal, thus she suffers a reduction in sales. Still, she has been able to increase her stock and attend to the family needs.

Nulu plans to open a wholesale shop. She has successfully paid back more than 10 loans.

loans.use: To increase her stock of charcoal

loans.name: Natiga

texts.en: Natiga H. is a 36-year-old woman who sells milk and yogurt to local people and neighbors. Mainly she keeps a cow for her family and sells the rest of the milk. No one in her family has a job so selling milk and poultry sometimes brings some money to their family. Their main source of income is an Internally Displaced People benefit, which is about $70 USD a month. This amount is not enough to cover their basic family needs. Natiga wants to focus more on selling dairy products, which is why she applied for the loan of $800 USD to purchase one milk cow.

loans.use: To purchase one milk cow.

loans.name: Mujeres Esforzadas Group

texts.en:
Josefina is a 40- yearold woman who lives with her three children in the Barrio of Ginebra Arzerno on the north coast of the Dominican Republic. She has a small business selling watches, and she hopes that in the future she will be a successful and respected business woman. With this loan she will buy more inventory for her business, and will make some cosmetic improvements to her store as well. When she is not working, she enjoys spending time with her children and watching TV. Esperanza is looking forward to seeing this group of women succeed as they take the first step to improving their economic situation.

Note: This is a group loan. In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Thank you for your support!

loans.use: To buy a larger selection of watches for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Elbrus

texts.en: Elbrus K. is a 50-year-old man who sells dairy products such as milk and yogurt in the southern region of the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement. He has more than 20 years of experience in this field. His main financial source is selling dairy products to local people and to the local milk factory. His current income is just enough to cover his family's basic needs. As well, much of the dairy products Elbrus keeps in the family, which uses the milk and yogurt as their main everyday meal. He decided to purchase two calves for $400 USD each and raise them as milk cows. The raising period of a middle-size calf takes approximately two to three months.

loans.use: To purchase two calves for milk cows.

loans.name: Shani Ngatula's Tushirikiane Group

texts.en:
Shani, age 54, is a widow and has nine children. She runs a clothing business and a chicken business to provide for her family. She started selling clothing in 1995, while she started the chicken business recently with a previous loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. From her businesses, she is able to make about $85 a month. She works from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. daily.

In the past, Shani took three previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania and repaid them successfully. She now hopes for a new loan to buy more clothing, chicks, and chicken feed to increase her businesses.

In the picture, Shani is third from the left.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell, plus chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience E. lives in the town of Okoko, in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells kerosene to customers from two storage tanks which she owns. She has been in this business since 1998. Patience is 39 years old and married with four children. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years, and has applied for a new loan of $1,200 to buy more kerosene to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami A. is a 32-year-old man who keeps cows for the sale of dairy products. He has more that 10 years experience in this field. He is married and has three children; they all live in the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement. He purchased his last two cows with his first loan that he borrowed from Aqroinvest. He has successfully completed its repayment and now he is applying for this second loan. As selling dairy products is the main financial source for his family, Nizami is focused on expanding his business. For this reason, he has applied for a loan of $800 USD. He will use this loan to purchase one milk cow.

loans.use: To purchase one milk cow.
